subject: RE: [junit] generating historical graph of test results
msgSnippet: ... Actually, I believe that what Agitar does is different from what Bradley is asking.  If I understood correctly, Agitar monitors test runs, analyzes what
messageBody:
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Robert Watkins

> Bradley, Todd wrote:
> > Has anyone else put something like this together? Mike mentioned he's
> > heard of others who want to build such a results graphing tool, but
> > didn't know if anyone's got one they're sharing. So I'm posting here,
> > looking for pointers.
>
> Bradley, I've been thinking of something similar.
>
> I understand that Agitar's tool can do something like this,
> which may be a starting point if you've got more money than
> time (I don't know the price of Agitator, but I understand
> it's not cheap).

Actually, I believe that what Agitar does is different from what Bradley is
asking. If I understood correctly, Agitar monitors test runs, analyzes what
values are passed to your tests and then creates more tests with
combinations of these values.

From my experience, what Bradley is trying to achieve is *very* common and
I've seen many occurrences of companies storing months of test results in
databases, XML files or Excel spreadsheet. It's invaluable to get a sense
of the velocity of the quality of your product.

As for a practical solution, it seems to me it should be pretty easy to
write this kind of support as a test plug-in that would monitor the test
results and store them in the right place, but I'm not aware of any product
that does that today.

--
